fields.tagline: Save timestamped notes from your terminal and search them later.
fields.idea:
I kept losing scratch notes from ad‑hoc terminal sessions. I wanted a single command to append a timestamped note to a searchable log.

I built Kaydet for myself, then realized a few colleagues had the same itch.
fields.tech:
Python CLI with Click. App writes newline‑delimited JSON to a local file; optional sync to S3. Full‑text search via SQLite FTS5. Packaged for macOS/Linux via pipx.

Chose a file‑first approach to keep it portable and avoid servers.
fields.failure:
- Distribution: Developers liked the idea but the audience was too small to sustain growth.
- Product gap: People wanted mobile capture and cross‑platform search. Building sync and conflict resolution ballooned scope.
- Competition: Obsidian/Notion were “good enough” with hotkeys and plugins.

Revenue never covered the time to build sync safely.
fields.lessons:
- Start with the distribution channel, not features.
- If sync is on the horizon, either commit fully or avoid it entirely.
- A delightful CLI is not enough if the user’s capture surface is multi‑device.

fields.tagline: A blockchain dice game using Chainlink VRF for fairness.
fields.idea: Crypto casinos felt shady. I wanted a simple game with verifiable randomness using Chainlink VRF, transparent odds, and no hidden edges.
fields.tech: Solidity smart contract on Polygon. Chainlink VRF for randomness. Minimal Next.js frontend and WalletConnect. The house edge and bankroll managed by a single owner wallet.
fields.failure:
- Regulation: Even a harmless dice game raised legal questions in multiple regions.
- Trust: Users still preferred known brands; self‑hosted bankroll felt risky.
- Unit economics: Gas spikes killed micro‑bets. The more we subsidized fees, the higher the variance on a tiny bankroll.

We shut it down before exposure grew beyond our risk tolerance.
fields.lessons:
- “Provably fair” does not replace brand trust and compliance.
- On‑chain UX is fragile to gas price volatility.
- If regulation is a maybe, it’s a no for a tiny team.

fields.tagline: An AI inbox triage plugin for Gmail that never cleared the runway.
fields.idea: I wanted an AI assistant that labels newsletters, snoozes low‑value threads, and escalates critical ones. The goal: finish daily email in under 10 minutes.
fields.tech: Gmail API + Pub/Sub push notifications. A small Django service handled OAuth, stored minimal metadata, and called an LLM for routing. No email bodies persisted; everything was ephemeral.
fields.failure:
- API quotas and review cycles slowed iteration to a crawl.
- Privacy concerns: Even with no body storage, users hesitated to grant full mailbox scopes.
- Value signal: People liked the idea but didn’t pay once free trials ended. Email pain is high, willingness to pay was low.
fields.lessons:
- Trust and compliance work overshadowed product work.
- Shaving seconds off routine tasks is not always a strong buying trigger.
- Building on third‑party APIs means living with their pace.

fields.tagline: Local kitchens + delivery time slots, without building a courier fleet.
fields.idea: We wanted to connect home‑style kitchens to office workers with predictable time slots and pre‑orders. Reduce waste for cooks, cheaper lunch for customers.
fields.tech: Django + HTMX for a lightweight ops dashboard. Drivers onboarded via a simple app. Route batching with OR‑Tools. Payments via Stripe Connect.
fields.failure:
- Cold start: We had to recruit both kitchens and customers at the same time.
- Perishable ops: One missed batch ruined the day’s trust.
- Margins: After refunds, driver bonuses, and packaging, there was nothing left.

When one driver quit mid‑route, we spent the evening delivering meals ourselves.
fields.lessons:
- Logistics businesses need local redundancy from day one.
- Batching + perishables + peak windows leave razor‑thin margin for error.
- If your “MVP” requires heroics, it’s not minimal.

fields.tagline: Spin up a fast, clean landing page with copy prompts in minutes.
fields.idea: Founders over‑tune landing pages. We wanted sensible defaults, opinionated sections, and prompts to write compelling copy in English without overthinking.
fields.tech: Next.js static export. Prebuilt sections with tailwind. AI prompts for copy suggestions. One‑click deploy to Cloudflare Pages.
fields.failure:
- Competition: So many site builders with better ecosystems and integrations.
- Retention: After launch, users churned because they rarely needed a second site.
- Willingness to pay: The moment people needed extras (forms, auth), they switched to a bigger tool.
fields.lessons:
- Go where a platform lock‑in is a feature, not a bug.
- One‑time creation tools need a strong upsell path or consulting component.
- Copy prompts alone don’t create durable value.
